section-block.rac_essential-question: What foods do we like? Where do they come from?

section-block.rac_book_caption: Big Book: Baby Goes to Market

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Atinuke and illustrated by Angela Brooksbank
section-block.rac_book_summary: This book tells the story of Baby who goes to the market with Mama to buy some food. There are many opportunities for counting as Baby places food in Mama’s basket while Mama isn’t looking!

section-block.rac_copyright_line: 978-1-338-64877-5. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Baby Goes to Market by Atinuke, illustrated by Angela Brooksbank. Text copyright © 2017 by Atinuke. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Angela Brooksbank. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press.

section-block.rac_body-text: Hold up two fingers on one hand, and ask how many there are. Hold up one finger on your other hand. Ask, How many are there now? Repeat, this time taking one away.
Ask a child to name a favorite fruit. Guide children to repeat the word and clap once per syllable: ap-ple (clap, clap). Repeat until each child says the name of a fruit.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Baby Goes to Market by Atinuke and Angela Brooksbank.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use the Lala the Lizard Puppet.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Lala is here to read with us. She loves to count in stories like this one!
There is a question I want you to think about as we read:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is one food Baby gets at the market?

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Operations: Ask children to count the foods that Baby adds to Mama’s basket using their fingers as a support.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: We are going to read about a mother and her baby who go to the market. Does this look like the market where your family buys food? How is it the same? How is it different?
How many bananas did Baby put in Mama’s basket? Let’s show the number on our fingers!
I see a yam in Mama’s basket, too. Let’s count forward once from five. How many pieces of food are in Mama’s basket in all?
Baby is grinning in this picture! How do you think Baby is feeling? (MB)
How many biscuits does Mr. Momo give Baby? Let’s point to the right number!
Let’s count the children waving at Baby! We can count forward once more. How many fingers do we have up now?
Let’s talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is one food Baby gets at the market?
section.rac_body-text: Guide children to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask children to share their responses.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud short sentences about what Baby and Mama got at the market.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does Baby get bananas at the market?
At the market, Baby gets b_____ (bananas).
At the market, Baby gets bananas.
If you were at the market, what would you give Baby?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Understanding that large words can be broken down into smaller parts, or syllables, can make it easier for children to learn how to read and write. One way to find syllables in words is by clapping. Say market with the children, and clap on each syllable. Challenge students to count the syllables in banana.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Talk About the Feelings of Others

rac_body-text.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Everyone has feelings. Sometimes, others might not feel the same way you do about the same things! It’s important to be thoughtful about other people’s feelings and try to understand how they might see things differently. Stories like Baby Goes to Market are a great way to practice discovering how other people feel.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will revisit Baby Goes to Market. We will practice thinking about feelings by asking questions about how the characters feel.
When Clifford reads stories, he loves to think about how the characters are feeling! That way, he can understand them better.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Numerals: Hold up Number Cards and ask children to point to the correct one as you read aloud how many items Baby puts into the basket.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How many bananas does Baby have? Let’s point to the right number!
But oh no! Baby is eating one banana! Let’s count backward once from six. How many bananas are left?
Mama does not notice the bananas. How do you think Mama feels in this picture? What do you think she is noticing instead? (MB)
Baby is grinning. How do people feel when they grin? (MB)
How many people are selling palm oil? Let’s point to the right number!
Two of them are sleeping. Let’s count backward twice from five. How many sellers are left awake?
How do you think Mama feels when she looks at her basket? How can you tell? Why do you think Mama feels that way? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Have children play feelings charades. Encourage a child to choose one feeling and act it out: happy, sad, angry, surprised, or tired. Ask the class to guess what feeling the child is expressing. Repeat, making sure each child has a turn to act.
Transcribe children’s speech as they describe the feelings other children are acting out.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Recognizing and understanding other people’s feelings is important for children as they develop relationships. If children struggle to notice how other people feel, it can help to use concrete terms to describe feelings, act out feelings, and provide positive feedback when children are successful at noticing feelings. (Denham & Burton, 2003)

section-block.rac_body-text: Review adding on and taking away. Using a group of Connecting Cubes, model adding and taking one cube away. Ask children to count with you to find the new amount.
Have three children stand inside the circle. Count them aloud. Ask one child to join them. How many are in the circle now? Let’s count forward once! Repeat with other numbers.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Baby Goes to Market by Atinuke and illustrated by Angela Brooksbank.
Lala loves reading stories with lots of healthy foods to count!
As we read today, think about this question: What is one way Baby feels at the market?

section.rac_body-text: Encourage children to count items at the market using their fingers as support. Facilitate back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Baby feels surprised! What do you notice in this picture? How can you tell how Baby feels? (MB)
How many foods in Mama’s basket are yellow? Let’s count!
section.rac_body-text: Count five bananas and one palm oil.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The pineapple is also yellow. Let’s count forward once from six to add one pineapple! There are seven yellow foods.
Baby has a smile on his face. How do you think Baby feels in this picture? How can you tell? (MB)
Let’s count all of the corn in this picture! Mrs. Kunle gives Baby three corn. Let’s count backward three times from eight to take away three corn.
How many roasted corn does Baby eat? Let’s point to the right number!
How many flip-flops is Mama getting? Let’s count!
Baby gets two coconut pieces. Let’s add the two flip-flops and the two coconut pieces. We can count forward two times from two. How many is that?
Did you listen and remember as we read the story today? What is one way Baby feels at the market?
section.rac_body-text: Ask children to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to choose several children to share their responses.
Possible reponses:
Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about buying food at the market.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How does Baby feel when he gets bananas?
How do you think you would feel if you went to this market?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: At this early stage, it’s important to focus on teaching children the basic concepts of addition and subtraction: putting together and taking away. Telling stories and using concrete objects to show numbers being added or taken away is a great way to encourage children to start using these concepts in the real world.

section-block.rac_body-text: Revisit and discuss the many foods mentioned in Baby Goes to Market. Ask children if they remember one healthy food that Baby ate.
Sing “Apples and Bananas” with children to get them excited to learn more healthy ways to eat fruit. Try switching fruits to “Oranges and Coconuts.”

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Let’s Make Fruit Salad! It is an informational poster that gives directions to make a fruit salad.
Baby Goes to Market and Let’s Make Fruit Salad! both focus on eating fruit. Let’s look for other connections between the two as we read.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Baby Goes to Market book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about this week’s question:
What foods do we like? Where do they come from?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, stopping to ask the questions below. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to respond.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This is a recipe for fruit salad. A recipe is a set of directions that tell you how to make something. Do you remember what fruit salad is?
This recipe has many ingredients!
section.rac_body-text: Point to the 3 on the Big Chart.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How many bananas do we need?
Where could we go to buy these fruits? Which fruit sounds the tastiest to you?
How many apples are in this picture? Let’s count!
The boy is holding one apple. How many apples are left? Let’s count back.
How do you think the children are feeling in this picture? Do they like the bananas? (MB)
Let’s count the mangoes in this picture. The boy doesn’t have one! Let’s pretend to give him one. How many are there now?

section.rac_body-text: Have children each draw their favorite fruits and cut them out. Then put the fruits together for a class fruit salad for everyone to enjoy!
Provide a writing prompt asking about foods children like. Give children feedback as they draw and write in response.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children can learn new languages more quickly with cognates. Cognates are words that share a common history and often look and sound similar. Help Spanish speakers build their vocabulary by teaching them cognates, like fruta (fruit), ensalada (salad), bayas (berries), and mango (mango).

section-block.rac_body-text: Show children where Africa is on a globe. Explain that people all over the world go to markets to buy food. Ask, Where do you go to get food?
Gather a cup or large bowl, and enough water to fill it. Invite children to watch as you pour some water inside. Ask, Is it full yet? Repeat, until the answer is yes!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s read Baby Goes to Market by Atinuke and illustrated by Angela Brooksbank one more time this week.
Who remembers whether this book teaches us information or tells us a story?
We learned about many foods, where they come from, and how we can eat them! When we read today, think about this quesiton:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: If you went to the market, what healthy food would you buy?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to select children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Mama’s basket is empty! How can you tell? Why does Mama go to the market with an empty basket?
Let’s pretend we are carrying an empty basket to the market!
Let’s count the chickens in this picture. What if one chicken walked away? Let’s count backward once from four. How many chickens are left?
Let’s count the oranges Baby is holding. Mr. Femi is giving Baby one more orange. Let’s count forward. How many oranges does Baby have now?
How many biscuits does Baby get?
Let’s pretend to eat a sugary biscuit! Let’s show how happy we are to taste it. (MB)
Mama’s basket is full! How did it get full?
Let’s pretend we are carrying a full basket! Let’s act like we are tired because it’s very heavy. (MB)
If you went to the market, what healthy food would you buy?
section.rac_body-text: Have students Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share with the group.
Possible responses:
Invite children to draw or write a story about buying food at the market and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What healthy yellow fruit could you buy at the market?
At the market, I could buy b___ (bananas).
At the market, I could buy bananas.
What recipe could you make with that healthy food?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: What children hear and think about eating healthy when they are young can greatly affect how they feel about themselves and their diet later on in life. Help encourage healthy eating thoughts and habits by being a role model. Talk about the healthy foods you like to eat, and what you find tasty about them.
